member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.CallbackHandler
member.summary: HttpHandler that enables server-side methods to be asynchronously called from the client by a control.
member.remarks: By assigning this handler to a page in Web.config's httpHandlers section, the page gets the ability to have its public methods marked with the attribute be accessible on the client via AJAX calls. The client-side method of the same name will return the value returned by its server-side counterpart.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.SiteMap
member.summary: Displays a customizable listing of contents of hirerachical data.

remarks.para: The SiteMap control produces a visual representation of hierarchical data, typically a site map loaded from an XML file specified using the property.
The type of layout is selected using the property. The property can be used to define a table-like layout for breaking up the site map into separate cells.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.BaseNavigator.CustomAttributeMappings
member.summary: Custom attribute mappings. Provides the ability to re-map property names when they are looked up in XML.
member.example:
Suppose the Menu structure is being loaded from an XML file named MenuData.xml with contents like this:
<node> <node txt="circle" pic="images/circle.gif" alt="Roundish Circle" /> <node txt="square" pic="images/square.gif" alt="Squarish Square" /> </node>
The names of the XML attributes in this file do not correspond to the names of the relevant MenuItem properties. An easy way to work around this problem is to use CustomAttributeMappings. Here is how this can be done:
<ComponentArt:Menu ID="Menu1" SiteMapXmlFile="MenuData.xml" runat="server"> <CustomAttributeMappings> <ComponentArt:CustomAttributeMapping From="alt" To="ToolTip" /> <ComponentArt:CustomAttributeMapping From="pic" To="Look-LeftIconUrl" /> <ComponentArt:CustomAttributeMapping From="txt" To="Text" /> </CustomAttributeMappings> </ComponentArt:Menu>

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu
member.summary: Displays a pop-up menu in the web page.

remarks.para: Creates a pop-up Menu on the web page. Depending on its property, the Menu can act as a permanent part of the page, or as a context menu that is activated by some user action.

Menu contents are organized as a hierarchy of objects, accessed via the property. There are a number of ways to manipulate the menu's contents:
Using the Menu designer to visually set up the structure.
Inline within the aspx (or ascx) file, by nesting the item structure within the Menu tag's inner property tag <Items>.
From an XML file specified by the property.
Programmatically on the server by using the server-side API. For an introduction, see Creating a Menu in Code.
Programmatically on the client by using the client-side API. For more information, see Overview of Web.UI Client-side Programming and client-side reference for Menu and MenuItem classes.

Menu styles are largely specified via CSS classes, which need to be defined separate from the Menu. The CSS classes and other presentation-related settings are then assigned via various properties of the Menu and related classes. For more information see Look and Feel Properties.
In order to streamline the setting of presentation properties for menu items, many of the properties are grouped within the object. To learn more about , see ItemLook Concepts and Overview of ItemLooks in ComponentArt Navigation Controls.
Further customization of item styles and contents can be accomplished with and . For more information on templates, see Overview of Templates in Web.UI.
A menu with no information specified will be rendered with a default set of CSS class definitions and assignments.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.BuildItemStorage(ComponentArt.Web.UI.MenuItem,System.Collections.ArrayList,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the array of item properties that are to be propagated to the client side.
member.param: The item that is being processed.
Array of item property arrays. Item property array of the current item gets appended to it.
Client-side storage index of the parent item of the currently processed item.
Depth at which we are currently processing. Needed to know when to stop if RenderDrillDownDepth is significant.
member.returns: Client-side storage index of the item that has just been processed.
member.remarks:
This is a recursive method which will also process all of the item's child items.
The order of the ArrayList elements must match the order of their client-side equivalents in the menu properties array in A573W888.js.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ProcessScrollLook(ComponentArt.Web.UI.ItemLook,System.String)
member.summary: Generates the array of look properties that are to be propagated to the client side.
member.param: The look that is being propagated.
member.remarks: This is currently used only to propagate the effective look of up and down scrolls. Since the scrolls ignore many look properties (like all those related to icons or expanded items), we omit many properties in this method. In the future we can modify this method to propagate the looks for all the items, too. Note: this is not the method used to propagate the looks in ItemLooks collection.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.AutoPostBackOnCheckChanged
member.summary: Whether to perform a postback when an item is checked or unchecked.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.CascadeCollapse
member.summary: Whether to collapse the groups in order or simultaneously.
member.value: When CascadeCollapse is true, groups are collapsed in order, a parent group starting to collapse only after its child group has finished collapsing. When it is false, all groups collapse at the same time. Default value is true.
member.remarks: If is zero or if both and are None, CascadeCollapse will have no visible effect.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ContextControlId
member.summary: Client-side ID of the element to which this context menu is bound.
member.remarks: This property is only in effect when is set to ControlSpecific.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ContextData
member.summary: Value that was passed to the context menu by the caller on the client side.
member.remarks:
This property is readonly on the server. It is intended to be edited only by client-side scripts.
This property is most often used when is set to Custom. A custom context menu is displayed by using ShowContextMenu method of the client-side Menu object. The last parameter of this method is optional and if supplied is used to set ContextData.
member.example:
In this example two controls share the same context menu and use its ContextData property to let the server know which one caused the postback. ContextData is set on the client in the ShowContextMenu function call.
<%@ Page Language="C#" %> <%@ Register TagPrefix="ComponentArt" Namespace="ComponentArt.Web.UI" Assembly="ComponentArt.Web.UI" %> <script runat="server"> void Page_Load() { if (Page.IsPostBack) { PostBackInfo.Text = "PostBack caused by " + Menu1.ContextData + " label."; } } </script> <html> <head> </head> <body> <form runat="server"> <asp:Label runat="server" ID="Cyan" BackColor="cyan" onclick="Menu1.ShowContextMenu(event,'cyan')">Cyan</asp:Label> <asp:Label runat="server" ID="Pink" BackColor="pink" onclick="Menu1.ShowContextMenu(event,'pink')">Pink</asp:Label> <asp:Label runat="server" ID="PostBackInfo">Not a PostBack</asp:Label> <ComponentArt:Menu runat="server" ID="Menu1" ContextMenu="Custom"> <Items> <ComponentArt:MenuItem Text="Click to PostBack" AutoPostBackOnSelect="True" /> </Items> </ComponentArt:Menu> </form> </body> </html>

member.summary: Delay between the mouse entering a MenuItem and its subgroup starting to expand.
member.value: Delay is expressed in milliseconds. Default value is 0.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ExpandDisabledItems
member.summary: Whether to expand a subgroup of an item that is disabled.
member.value: When false, the menu will not expand a subgroup of a disabled item. Default value is true.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ExpandOnClick
member.summary: Whether to wait for a click before expanding and collapsing the menu.
member.value: When true, the menu will not expand until it is clicked, and will then not collapse until a click away from of it. When false, the menu will expand on mouse over and collapse on mouse out, without waiting for clicks. Default value is false.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.HideSelectElements
member.summary: Whether to hide the select elements that would obscure the menu.
member.value: When true, the menu temporarily hides <select> elements that would obscure its pop-up groups. Default value is true.
member.remarks: HideSelectElements only has effect on Windows IE browsers and only when is not in effect.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.HighlightExpandedPath
member.summary: Whether to default to Hover look for the items whose child groups are expanded.
member.value: When false, the items default to their normal look when the mouse is over their expanded subgroup. When true, the items default to their hover look when the mouse is over their expanded subgroup. Default value is true.
member.remarks: There are many ways to override and fine-tune the behaviour specified by this property, for example via ExpandedCssClass and similar properties.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.Items
member.summary: Collection of root MenuItems.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.KeyboardEnabled
member.summary: Whether to enable keyboard control of the Menu.
member.value: When true, the menu responds to keyboard shortcuts. Default value is true.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.Orientation
member.summary: Orientation of the top group.
member.value: Default value is GroupOrientation.Horizontal.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.OverlayWindowedElements
member.summary: Whether to overlay windowed elements that would obscure the menu.
member.value: When true, the menu overlays windowed elements that would obscure its pop-up groups. When false, the menu does not attempt to overlay windowed elements. Default value is true.

remarks.para: OverlayWindowedElements only applies to Windows IE browsers. In particular, windowed element overlay is only available in IE 5.5+ on Windows.
Windowed elements include select boxes and embedded objects such as ActiveX controls and Java applets.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ScrollingEnabled
member.summary: Whether to enable scrolling for this Menu's groups.
member.value: When true, the menu implements scrolling of vertical groups that cannot fit all their items within their specified size or within the browser window. When false, the menu allows the groups to grow past those boundaries. Default is false.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.SelectedItem
member.summary: The selected item.
member.value: The item that is considered selected, or null if none is.
member.remarks: This property can be set on the server-side to force an item selection.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Menu.ServerCalculateProperties
member.summary: Whether to calculate item properties on the server.
member.value: When true, all menu item properties are pre-calculated on the server. Default is false.
member.remarks: If ServerCalculateProperties is set to true, classic item storage is used, with item properties being calculated on the server. This results in reduced client-side API capabilities, but can improve client-side performance for Menus with very large item structures (with thousands of menu items).

Only pop-up groups drop shadows
Shadows are only available in Internet Explorer 6 on Windows.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.GridLevel
member.summary: Represents a level (table) of data in a control.

remarks.para: The GridLevel class defines a level of data in the Grid. In a non-hierarchical Grid, there is only one level.

To define the content and style of a level of data for the Grid, set appropriate CSS style properties (like ) on the GridLevel and define a number of objects in the GridLevel's collection. At least one of these columns must contain unique values for each item loaded from the data source, and such a column can then be set as the for that level. Setting this property is a requirement for the proper functioning of the Grid.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Snap
member.summary: Enables user manipulation of a page fragment including collapse/expand, dock/undock, drag-and-drop.

remarks.para: The Snap control is a container for ASP.NET content. Contained in a Snap, content can be dragged around the page, docked inside DOM elements, expanded and collapsed, minimized, or aligned and made to float along as the page is scrolled.

ASP.NET content is defined in , and sections. Dragging is controlled by the property and is enabled by calling the client-side StartDragging method in the onmousedown event for one of the DOM elements placed into the Snap. To define docking containers, set the property to a comma-delimited list of DOM element IDs. Floating and alignment are controlled by the and properties. For expand/collapse functionality, use the client-side ToggleExpand method in an onclick handler for one of the DOM elements placed into the Snap.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.GridItem
member.summary: Represents an item (row) in a control.

remarks.para: The GridItem class is the interface the data loaded into the Grid. Each GridItem corresponds to a row from a table or an object from an array used as the data source. Individual values in a GridItem are accessed using a string (field name) or integer (field index) index on the GridItem.

member.summary: Content to render in asynchronised callback of a control.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.CallBack
member.summary: Provides asynchronised callback functionality and partial rendering of page fragments without the need for full page postback.

remarks.para: The CallBack control consists of a container DOM element and the ability to refresh its content via AJAX callbacks. A client-side object with an ID corresponding to the server-side control is exposed, with a simple client-side API.

The main part of the client-side API is the Callback method, which is used to initiate an AJAX request, send parameters to a server-side event handler and allow it to render new content to the output stream.
In addition to the server-side event, there is a number of client-side events which can be used to react to callback actions, such as and .

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.CallBack.CacheContent
member.summary: Whether to cache content. If set, callbacks will only be made the first time for each unique parameter used. Default: false.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.CallBack.CallbackPrefix
member.summary: Callback prefix to use instead of the computed one.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.CallBack.CatchServerErrors
member.summary: Whether to catch server-side errors. If set, exceptions occuring during callback are caught and sent to the client where the callbackError event is raised. Default: true.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Utils.ConvertStringToJSString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to an appropriate JavaScript string constant.
member.returns: A string that represents the given string in javascript. A null string converts to string "null". All other strings convert to a single-quoted javascript string ("example" converts to "'example'"). Care is taken to make sure the characters ' and \ are escaped properly.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Utils.ConvertUnitToJSConstant(System.Web.UI.WebControls.Unit)
member.summary: Converts a Unit to an appropriate JavaScript constant.
member.returns: A string that represents the unit in javascript. Unit.Empty converts to string "null". Units expressed in pixels convert to a string representing a javascript number (eg: "10"). All other Units convert to a quoted javascript string containing the numeric and the unit part (eg: "'10%'").

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Utils.ConvertUrl(System.Web.HttpContext,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Resolve the effective URL given its string, a base URL, and the HttpContext.
member.returns: Effective URL.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Utils.FindControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: Private recursive method called by the public FindControl method.
member.param: The container within which to search.
The subcontainer which has been searched previously, and may therefore be avoided now.
The ID of the control to find.
member.returns: The control with the given ID, or null if none exists in oTopControl.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Utils.FindControl(System.Web.UI.Control,System.String)
member.summary: Finds the control with the given ID in the proximity of the given control.
member.remarks: This method is much more intelligent than ASP.NET's FindControl method. For starters, it recurses into containers. Secondly, it starts the search in the vicinity of the given control, and then moves further away. This is necessary for FindControl to properly work for situations like TabStrips+MultiPages across various user controls, master pages, etc.
member.param: The control near which to start the search.
The ID of the control to search for.
member.returns: The control with the given ID, or null if none exists in the page.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.ComboBox
member.summary: Displays a combo box in a web page, offering functionality to select an item from a list.

remarks.para: The ComboBox control consists of an input box and an associated dropdown, which is displayed on demand. The dropdown can include data items loaded from a database, defined inline on the ASPX page, or created programmatically. It can also contained custom ASP.NET content.

Notable features of ComboBox include load-on-demand for large datasets (with caching), auto-filter, auto-highlight and auto-complete functionality, dynamic resizing ability, as well as highly customizable display elements.
In addition to the server-side API, ComboBox also exposes rich functionality on the client.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar
member.summary: Provides date manipulation interface with a browsable month-view table or a customized text box.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of property, creates a Calendar or a Picker on the page.
Both calendar and picker can have their date range limited using and properties.
A Calendar is a table with a cell for each day. Depending on the values of and properties, the calendar can show one or more months.

Zero, one or more of the days can be selected by the user or programmatically - on the server or on the client. property contains the collection of selected dates. It is possible to customize selection options, using properties like , , , and . Days can be designated as unselectable, by adding them to collection.

Appearance of the day cells can be customized based on a number of factors. Today's day, weekend days, selected days, disabled days, and days that are out of range can all have specific appearance. More than one appearance can be in effect, as described in Composing Calendar Day Styles tutorial. Appearance of days can be further customized using the collection.
A Picker is a customized textbox, which reacts to various mouse and keyboard commands to show a date value. Unlike a calendar, a picker always shows exactly one date, reflected by property.

member.name: F:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.MaxDateTime
member.summary: Specifies the maximum date value of the Calendar control. This field is read-only.
member.remarks:
The maximum date is set to 12/31/9998 23:59:59.
Use to adjust the settable range of dates.

member.name: F:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.MinDateTime
member.summary: Specifies the minimum date value of the Calendar control. This field is read-only.
member.remarks:
The minimum date is set to 1/1/1753 00:00:00.
Use to adjust the settable range of dates.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.AbbreviatedDayNames
member.summary: Gets or sets a one-dimensional array of type containing the culture-specific abbreviated names of the days of the week.
member.value: A one-dimensional array of type containing the culture-specific abbreviated names of the days of the week. This property corresponds to DateTimeFormatInfo.AbbreviatedDayNames
member.remarks: This property gets modified when is set.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.AbbreviatedMonthNames
member.summary: Gets or sets a one-dimensional array of type containing the culture-specific abbreviated names of the months.
member.value: A one-dimensional array of type containing the culture-specific abbreviated names of the months. In a 12-month calendar, the 13th element of the array is an empty string. This property corresponds to DateTimeFormatInfo.AbbreviatedMonthNames. Unlike DateTimeFormatInfo.AbbreviatedMonthNames, this property allows you to set it to an array of length 12. However, when getting this value, it always returns an array of length 13.
member.remarks: This property gets modified when is set.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.AllowDaySelection
member.summary: Whether the control allows selection of single days.
member.value: true if the control allows selection of single days; otherwise, false. The default value is true.
member.remarks: This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.AllowMonthSelection
member.summary: Whether the control shows month selectors.
member.value: true if the control shows the selectors that select all days in a month; otherwise, false. The default value is false.
member.remarks: This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.AllowMultipleSelection
member.summary: Whether the control allows selection of multiple dates.
member.value: true if the control allows the selection of more than one date entry; otherwise, false. The default value is false.
member.remarks:
When or are set to true, the week and month selectors still select multiple dates even when AllowMultipleSelection is set to false. In these situations selection is limited to only one week or one month. To show a control with no selectable dates, set all of , , and to false.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.AllowWeekSelection
member.summary: Whether the control shows week selectors.
member.value: true if the control shows the selectors that select all days in a week; otherwise, false. The default value is false.
member.remarks: This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.CellPadding
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of space between the contents of a cell and the cell's border.
member.value: The amount of space (in pixels) between the contents of a cell and the cell's border. The default value is 2.
member.exception: The specified cell padding is less than -1.
member.remarks:
Use this property to control the spacing between the contents of a cell and the cell's border. The padding amount specified is added to all four sides of a cell. Individual cell sizes cannot be specified. Setting this property to -1 indicates that this property is not set in the rendered table.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.CellSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of space between cells.
member.value: The amount of space (in pixels) between cells. The default value is 0.
member.exception: The specified cell spacing is less than -1.
member.remarks:
Use this property to control the spacing between individual cells in the calendar. This spacing is applied both vertically and horizontally. Setting this property to -1 indicates that this property is not set in the rendered table.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.ClientSideOnAfterVisibleDateChanged
member.summary: Client-side function to call after the Calendar control finishes a month swap.
member.remarks:
The function is passed the client-side Calendar object.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.
ClientSideOnAfterVisibleDateChanged is an event that fires after a month swap animation finishes. Not every change of is accompanied by a month swap animation, so it is possible to have fire without ClientSideOnAfterVisibleDateChanged firing. However, when there is a month swap animation, ClientSideOnAfterVisibleDateChanged and will both fire, and in this case the order of firing is always: ClientSideOnBeforeVisibleDateChanged, ClientSideOnVisibleDateChanged, ClientSideOnAfterVisibleDateChanged.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.ClientSideOnBeforeVisibleDateChanged
member.summary: Client-side function to call before the Calendar control starts a month swap.
member.remarks:
The function is passed the client-side Calendar object.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.
ClientSideBeforeVisibleDateChanged is an event that fires before a month swap animation starts. Not every change of is accompanied by a month swap animation, so it is possible to have fire without ClientSideBeforeVisibleDateChanged firing. However, when there is a month swap animation, ClientSideBeforeVisibleDateChanged and will both fire, and in this case the order of firing is always: ClientSideOnBeforeVisibleDateChanged, ClientSideOnVisibleDateChanged, ClientSideOnAfterVisibleDateChanged.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.PickerCustomFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the custom date format string.
member.value: A string that represents the custom date format.
member.remarks:
To display string literals that contain date format strings you must escape the substring. For example, to display the date as "05 de Mayo" (with MonthNames set to Spanish words like "Mayo"), set the PickerCustomFormat property to "dd 'de' MMMM". If the "de" substring is not escaped, the result is "05 5e Mayo" because the "d" character is read as the one-letter day format string (see the format string table below).
To show a single quote (') character within an escaped substring, enter it twice (''). You can not show a single quote character outside of an escaped substring. The property must be set to Custom for PickerCustomFormat to affect the formatting of the displayed date. The following table lists all the valid format strings and their descriptions:
Format StringDescription
dThe one or two-digit day.
ddThe two-digit day. Single digit day values are preceded by a zero.
dddThe day-of-week abbreviation.
ddddThe full day-of-week name.
hThe one or two-digit hour in 12-hour format.
hh The two-digit hour in 12-hour format. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
HThe one or two-digit hour in 24-hour format.
HH The two-digit hour in 24-hour format. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
MThe one or two-digit month number.
MM The two-digit month number. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
MMMThe month abbreviation.
MMMMThe full month name.
sThe one or two-digit seconds.
ssThe two-digit seconds. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
tThe one-letter AM/PM abbreviation ("AM" is displayed as "A").
ttThe two-letter AM/PM abbreviation ("AM" is displayed as "AM").
yThe one-digit year (2001 is displayed as "1").
yyThe last two digits of the year (2001 is displayed as "01").
yyySame as yyyy
yyyyThe full year (2001 is displayed as "2001").
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Picker.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.PickerFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of date/time displayed by the picker.
member.value: One of the values. The default is Long.
member.remarks:
This property determines the date/time format of the picker's display. The resulting format is based on 's property. PickerFormat property must be set to Custom for the property to affect the formatting of the displayed date.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Picker.

member.value: The string designator for hours that are "post meridiem" (after noon). This property corresponds to DateTimeFormatInfo.PMDesignator
member.remarks: This property gets modified when is set.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.SelectedDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the selected date.
member.value: A object that represents the selected date. The default value is DateTime.MinValue, which indicates that no date is selected.
member.remarks:
The SelectedDate property and the collection are closely related. When , , and properties are all set to false, no more than one date can be selected, SelectedDate and SelectedDates[0] have the same value and SelectedDates.Count equals 1. When multiple dates can be selected, SelectedDate and SelectedDates[0] have the same value.
Setting the SelectedDate property has the side effect of setting the SelectedDates collection to a one-element collection containing the SelectedDate.
There is one special case. A SelectedDate of DateTime.MinValue indicates that SelectedDates collection is empty. Setting the SelectedDate property to DateTime.MinValue has a side effect of clearing the SelectedDates collection.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.SelectedDates
member.summary: Gets a collection of objects that represent the selected dates on the control.
member.remarks:
The property and the SelectedDates collection are closely related. When , , and properties are all set to false, no more than one date can be selected, SelectedDate and SelectedDates[0] have the same value and SelectedDates.Count equals 1. When multiple dates can be selected, SelectedDate and SelectedDates[0] have the same value.
Setting the SelectedDates collection has the side effect of setting the SelectedDate property to the first element of the collection.
There is one special case. A SelectedDate of DateTime.MinValue indicates that SelectedDates collection is empty. Clearing the SelectedDates collection has the side effect of setting the SelectedDate property to DateTime.MinValue.
You can also use the SelectedDates collection to programmatically select dates on the Calendar control. Use the Add, Remove, Clear, and SelectRange methods to programmatically manipulate the selected dates in the SelectedDates collection.
This property is most relevant when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar. If the property is set to CalendarControlType.Picker, property is of more interest.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TitleDateFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the date format string for date(s) shown in the calendar title.
member.value: A string that represents the custom date format for date(s) shown in the calendar title. Default is "MMMM yyyy", rendering as "February 2006" for example.
member.remarks:
To display string literals that contain date format strings you must escape the substring. For example, to display the date as "05 de Mayo" (with MonthNames set to Spanish words like "Mayo"), set the TitleDateFormat property to "dd 'de' MMMM". If the "de" substring is not escaped, the result is "05 5e Mayo" because the "d" character is read as the one-letter day format string (see the format string table below).
To show a single quote (') character within an escaped substring, enter it twice (''). You can not show a single quote character outside of an escaped substring. The following table lists all the valid format strings and their descriptions:
Format StringDescription
dThe one or two-digit day.
ddThe two-digit day. Single digit day values are preceded by a zero.
dddThe day-of-week abbreviation.
ddddThe full day-of-week name.
hThe one or two-digit hour in 12-hour format.
hh The two-digit hour in 12-hour format. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
HThe one or two-digit hour in 24-hour format.
HH The two-digit hour in 24-hour format. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
MThe one or two-digit month number.
MM The two-digit month number. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
MMMThe month abbreviation.
MMMMThe full month name.
sThe one or two-digit seconds.
ssThe two-digit seconds. Single digit values are preceded by a zero.
tThe one-letter AM/PM abbreviation ("AM" is displayed as "A").
ttThe two-letter AM/PM abbreviation ("AM" is displayed as "AM").
yThe one-digit year (2001 is displayed as "1").
yyThe last two digits of the year (2001 is displayed as "01").
yyySame as yyyy
yyyyThe full year (2001 is displayed as "2001").
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar and the property is set to true.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TitleDateRangeSeparatorString
member.summary: Gets or sets the string that separates the to and from dates in the calendar title.
member.value: A string that separates the text of to and from dates when the calendar title shows a date range. Default value is " - ".
member.remarks: This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar and the property is set to true and the is set to CalendarTitleType.VisibleRangeText.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TitleType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of the contents displayed in the calendar title area.
member.value: A value indicating which kind of CalendarTitleType to display. Default is CalendarTitleType.VisibleDateText
member.remarks: This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar and the property is set to true.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TodayDayActiveCssClass
member.summary: Gets or sets the active CSS class for today's date on the control.
member.remarks:
Use this property to specify the active CSS class for today's date on the control. If the TodayDayActiveCssClass property is not set, the CSS class specified in the property is used.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TodayDayCssClass
member.summary: Gets or sets the CSS class for today's date on the control.
member.remarks:
Use this property to specify the CSS class for today's date on the control. If the TodayDayCssClass property is not set, the CSS class specified in the property is used.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TodayDayHoverCssClass
member.summary: Gets or sets the hover CSS class for today's date on the control.
member.remarks:
Use this property to specify the hover CSS class for today's date on the control. If the TodayDayHoverCssClass property is not set, the CSS class specified in the property is used.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.TodaysDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the value for today's date.
member.value: A object that contains the value that the control considers to be today's date. If this property is not explicitly set, this date will be the date on the server.
member.remarks: The appearance of date specified by the TodaysDate property can be customized by using the property. If the property is not set, the date specified by the TodaysDate property determines which date is displayed in the control. This property is only significant if property is set to true. If it is set to false, client's clock will be used to determine today's date, and the value of TodaysDate property will have no bearing on VisibleDate property or on appearance of the date it specifies.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.ToggleSelectOnCtrlKey
member.summary: Whether to toggle day selection only when it is Ctrl + clicked. Default is true.
member.value: true if the control toggles selected date only when a date is clicked with Ctrl key held down. false if every click toggles whether the date is selected. The default value is true.
member.remarks:
If this property is set to true, when a date is clicked without the Ctrl key, it becomes the lone selected date.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar and property is set to true.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.UseServersTodaysDate
member.summary: Whether the control should use server's clock for determining today's date.
member.value: true if the control uses the server's clock to determine today's date; false if it uses the client's clock. The default value is true.
member.remarks: If UseServersTodaysDate property is set to true, today's date specified in property is used. Otherwise, client's clock determines today's date.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.VisibleDate
member.summary: Gets or sets the date that is displayed in the control.
member.value: A object that specifies the date that control displays. The default value is DateTime.MinValue, indicating to default to .
member.remarks:
If VisibleDate property is set to DateTime.MinValue, but property is set to false, VisibleDate will attempt to default to client's today's date, and TodaysDate property will be ignored.
This property is most relevant when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar. If the property is set to CalendarControlType.Picker, property is of more interest.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.VisibleMonthColumn
member.summary: Gets or sets the column in the Calendar in which the visible month is displayed.
member.value: The number of the column of the control in which the visible month is displayed. Default is 1.
member.remarks:
This property is one-delimited. The leftmost column is numbered 1.
The value of VisibleMonthColumn must be at least 1 and no more than the value of property.
Which month is visible is determined by property.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.
member.exception: The specified column number is less than 1 or more than the value of MonthColumns property.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Calendar.VisibleMonthRow
member.summary: Gets or sets the row in the Calendar in which the visible month is displayed.
member.value: The number of the row of the control in which the visible month is displayed. Default is 1.
member.remarks:
This property is one-delimited. The topmost row is numbered 1.
The value of VisibleMonthRow must be at least 1 and no more than the value of property.
Which month is visible is determined by property.
This property only applies when the property is set to CalendarControlType.Calendar.
member.exception: The specified row number is less than 1 or more than the value of MonthRows property.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.NavBarItem
member.summary: Navigation node class for the control.

remarks.para: A NavBarItem object corresponds to a node in a . NavBarItem are created on the fly as data is loaded from a data source, or can be created and added to the NavBar rogrammatically. They can also be defined inline, inside NavBar's collection.
Typically, a NavBar node needs to have its and properties set, with some associated action on click, such as a to go to, or a to execute.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.MultiPage
member.summary: Manages a collection of page fragments, all occupying the same section of the page, only one of them visible at a time.

remarks.para: The MultiPage control manages sections of content layered on top of each other, with only one section visible at any one time. A MultiPage contains a number of controls, each containing ASP.NET content to be rendered for one visible section.
By default, the PageViews are rendered all at once, and their visibility is manipulated on the client. Alternatively by setting and to true, content will be changed via postback.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.ToolBar
member.summary: Displays a toolbar in the web page.

remarks.para: Creates a toolbar on the web page.

ToolBar contents are organized as an ordered collection of objects, accessed via the property. There are a number of ways to manipulate the toolbar's contents:
Using the ToolBar designer to visually set up the structure.
Inline within the aspx (or ascx) file, by nesting the item list within the ToolBar tag's inner property tag <Items>.
From an XML file specified by the property.
Programmatically on the server by using the server-side API.
Programmatically on the client by using the client-side API. For more information, see client-side reference for ToolBar and ToolBarItem classes.

ToolBar styles are largely specified via CSS classes, which need to be defined separate from the ToolBar. The CSS classes and other presentation-related settings are then assigned via various properties of the ToolBar and related classes.
Further customization of item designs and contents can be accomplished with and and custom collections.
A toolbar with no information specified will be rendered with a default set of CSS class definitions and assignments.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Splitter
member.summary: Divides its contents into a number of sections that the user can resize, expand and collapse.

remarks.para: Splitter provides the ability to easily define layouts consisting of different pane configurations. Once defined, panes can be resized, collapsed and expanded.

Layouts are defined in the collection. A consists of a which in turn contains a number of objects. Each SplitterPane defines styles for that particular pane, and references a object contained in Splitter's collection. SplitterPaneContent wraps any ASP.NET content that is to be used in a SplitterPane. Each SplitterPane also contains a collection, making it possible to nest SplitterPaneGroups inside SplitterPanes.

With most types of content, the event should be used to set the correct size of DOM elements on the client when a pane is resized. This is usually necessary in order to guarantee the proper functioning of Splitter resizing.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeView
member.summary: Uses a tree structure like file directories to display hierarchical data and allow its manipulation.

remarks.para: Data is loaded via the property (for local XML files), property (for XmlDocument or DataSet objects). Data can also be added programmatically or inline, by populating the collection with objects.

Besides CSS, TreeView's presentation can be modified using templates. There are two kinds of templates which can be used: and . Client templates consist of markup and client-side binding expressions and are the suggested way of templating for situations where ASP.NET controls are not required.
AJAX load-on-demand functionality is provided via the property. If set on the node, it will be expandable, and its expansion will result in XML data being loaded from the provided URL.
Data can be manipulated on the client via the client-side API. Any changes made to items on the client will persist to the server on postback.

member.summary: Client-side event handler to call when a node is copied. This is the identifier of a client script function which takes as its parameters two client-side TreeViewNode objects, the node being copied and its new parent node. The function should return a boolean value indicating whether the event should be canceled.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeView.ClientSideOnNodeExpand
member.summary: Client-side event handler to call when a node is expanded. This is the identifier of a client script function which takes as its parameter a client-side TreeViewNode object. The function should return a boolean value indicating whether the event should be canceled.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeView.ClientSideOnNodeExternalDrop
member.summary: Client-side event handler to call when a node is dropped on an external target. This is the identifier of a client script function which takes as its parameters a client-side TreeViewNode object and a DOM element on which the node was dropped.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeView.ClientSideOnNodeMove
member.summary: Client-side event handler to call when a node is moved. This is the identifier of a client script function which takes as its parameters two client-side TreeViewNode objects: the node which was moved, and its new parent node. The boolean value which the function should return determines whether the action will proceed (true) or be canceled (false).

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeView.ClientSideOnNodeRename
member.summary: Client-side event handler to call when a node is renamed. This is the identifier of a client script function which takes as its parameters the client-side node (TreeViewNode) which was edited, and its new label (string). The boolean value which the function should return determines whether the action will proceed (true) or be canceled (false).

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeView.ClientSideOnNodeSelect
member.summary: Client-side event handler to call when a node is selected. The function should return a boolean value indicating whether the event should be canceled.

member.summary: Whether to load the entire structure, including all load-on-demand nodes, when searching for the current node.
member.remarks: Setting this to true will cause TreeView to load all data from node ContentCallbackUrls before looking for the current node based on the request URL. If found in load-on-demand substructures, only the current path will remain loaded - all other load-on-demand subtrees will be unloaded. Using this feature will likely affect server-side performance.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip
member.summary: Creates multiple tabs, like dividers in a notebook or labels in a set of folders in a filing cabinet.

remarks.para:
TabStrip contents are organized as a hierarchy of objects, accessed via the property. There are a number of ways to manipulate the tabstrip's contents:
Using the TabStrip designer to visually set up the structure.
Inline within the aspx (or ascx) file, by nesting the tab structure within the TabStrip tag's inner property tag <Tabs>.
From an XML file specified by the property.
Programmatically on the server by using the server-side API.
Programmatically on the client by using the client-side API. For more information, see Overview of Web.UI Client-side Programming and client-side reference for TabStrip and TabStripTab classes.

TabStrip styles are largely specified via CSS classes, which need to be defined separate from the TabStrip. The CSS classes and other presentation-related settings are then assigned via various properties of the TabStrip and related classes. For more information see Look and Feel Properties.
In order to streamline the setting of presentation properties for tabstrip tabs, many of the properties are grouped within the object. To learn more about , see ItemLook Concepts and Overview of ItemLooks in ComponentArt Navigation Controls.
Further customization of tab styles and contents can be accomplished with and . For more information on templates, see Overview of Templates in Web.UI.
A tabstrip with no information specified will be rendered with a default set of CSS class definitions and assignments.

There are a number of settings for customizing TabStrip's layout and behaviour:
Tabs can scroll within the tabstrip when is set to true.
While most tabstrips contain only a single level of tabs, multiple levels can be nested automatically, simply by organizing into a deeper hierarchy.
TabStrip can be oriented horizontally or vertically using property.
Contents of tabs can also be oriented in different ways using property.
Each group of tabs can be aligned in various ways using properties of type such as .
Tabs can be made to seemingly overlap by using tab separators. For more information see Using Tab Separators.
TabStrip is often used in conjunction with control. For an example see Creating a Tabbed Dialog.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip.ProcessTab(ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStripTab,ComponentArt.Web.UI.JavaScriptArray@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates the array of tab properties that are to be propagated to the client side.
member.param: The tab that is being processed.
Array of tab property arrays. Tab property array of the current tab gets appended to it.
Client-side storage index of the parent tab of the currently processed tab.
Depth at which we are currently processing. Needed to know when to stop if RenderDrillDownDepth is significant.
member.returns: Client-side storage index of the tab that has just been processed.
member.remarks: This is a recursive method which will also process all of the tab's child tabs.
The method modifies this._childSelectedPostBackIDs.

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip.ProcessScrollLook(ComponentArt.Web.UI.ItemLook,System.String)
member.summary: Generates the array of look properties that are to be propagated to the client side.
member.param: The look that is being propagated.
member.remarks: This is currently used only to propagate the effective look of down, left, right and up scrolls. Since the scrolls ignore many look properties (like all those related to icons), we omit many properties in this method. In the future we can modify this method to propagate the looks for all the tabs, too. Note: this is not the method used to propagate the looks in the looks collection.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip.ClientEvents
member.summary: Client event handler definitions.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip.ClientSideOnTabMouseOut
member.summary: Client-side command to call when the mouse pointer leaves a tab. This can be any valid client script.
member.remarks:
Deprecated. Use ClientEvents.TabMouseOut instead. The function is passed a client-side TabStripTab object corresponding to the tab that fired the mouseout.
This is a tabstrip-wide event, called whenever the mouse pointer leaves any tab.
member.example: contains an example that uses ClientSideOnTabMouseOut.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip.ClientSideOnTabMouseOver
member.summary: Client-side command to call when the mouse pointer enters a tab. This can be any valid client script.
member.remarks:
Deprecated. Use ClientEvents.TabMouseOver instead. The function is passed a client-side TabStripTab object corresponding to the tab that fired the mouseover.
This is a tabstrip-wide event, called whenever the mouse pointer enters any tab.
member.example:
The following example displays in the window's status bar the text of the tab that the mouse pointer is over. is used in order to clear the window status when the mouse pointer leaves the tab.
<%@ Register TagPrefix="ComponentArt" Namespace="ComponentArt.Web.UI" Assembly="ComponentArt.Web.UI" %> <html> <head> <script type="text/javascript"> function tabMouseOver(tabstripTab) { window.status = tabstripTab.Text; } function tabMouseOut(tabstripTab) { window.status = ''; } </script> </head> <body> <form runat="server"> <ComponentArt:TabStrip ID="TabStrip1" runat="server" ClientSideOnTabMouseOver="tabMouseOver" ClientSideOnTabMouseOut="tabMouseOut"> <tabs> <ComponentArt:TabStripTab Text="Tab One" /> <ComponentArt:TabStripTab Text="Tab Two" /> </tabs> </ComponentArt:TabStrip> </form> </body> </html>

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TabStrip.ClientSideOnTabSelect
member.summary: Client-side function to call when a tab is selected. This can be any valid client script.
member.remarks:
Deprecated. Use ClientEvents.TabSelect instead. The function is passed a client-side TabStripTab object corresponding to the tab that was clicked. The function can cancel the select event by returning false.
This is a TabStrip-wide event, called whenever any tab is selected. For a tab-specific client-side action, use . Note that ClientSideOnTabSelect runs before ClientSideCommand, and can cancel its execution by returning false.
member.example:
The following example prompts the user to confirm the selection of the tab, and performs the postback only if the user chooses so.
<%@ Register Prefix="ComponentArt" Namespace="ComponentArt.Web.UI" Assembly="ComponentArt.Web.UI" %> <html> <head> <script type="text/javascript"> function ConfirmTabSelection(tab) { return confirm('Are you sure you want to select "' + tab.Text + '"?'); } </script> </head> <body> <form runat="server"> <ComponentArt:TabStrip ID="TabStrip1" runat="server" AutoPostBackOnSelect="true" ClientSideOnTabSelect="ConfirmTabSelection"> <tabs> <ComponentArt:TabStripTab Text="Tab One" /> <ComponentArt:TabStripTab Text="Tab Two" /> </tabs> </ComponentArt:TabStrip> </form> </body> </html>

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.TreeViewNode
member.summary: Navigation node class for the control.

remarks.para: A TreeViewNode object corresponds to a node in a . TreeViewNodes are created on the fly as data is loaded from a data source, or can be created and added to the TreeView rogrammatically. They can also be defined inline, inside TreeView's collection.
Typically, a TreeView node needs to have its and properties set, with some associated action on click, such as a to go to, or a to execute.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.NavBar
member.summary: Displays a sliding menu in the web page.

remarks.para: Data is loaded via the property (for local XML files), property (for XmlDocument or DataSet objects). Data can also be added programmatically or inline, by populating the collection with objects.

Besides CSS, NavBar's presentation can be modified using templates. There are two kinds of templates which can be used: and . Client templates consist of markup and client-side binding expressions and are the suggested way of templating for situations where ASP.NET controls are not required.

member.summary: Default height to apply to items.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.NavBar.DefaultItemSpacing
member.summary: Default spacing to provide between items.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.NavBar.FullExpand
member.summary: Whether to expand groups so they fill exactly the height of the NavBar.
member.remarks: If this property is set to true, ExpandSinglePath should also be set to true. The height of the NavBar will be constant and every group, when expanded, will expand to the same height, possibly causing some groups to have empty space below the items, and others to require scrolling.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.NavBar.ExpandSinglePath
member.summary: Whether to only permit a single path in the NavBar to be expanded at a time.
member.remarks: If this is set to true, every expansion will cause other groups at the same or lower level to collapse.

member.name: P:ComponentArt.Web.UI.NavBar.FillContainer
member.summary: Whether to take on the dimensions of the containing DOM element.
member.remarks: If this is set to true, Every client-side call to Render() will make the NavBar take on the dimensions of its parent DOM element.

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Grid
member.summary: Displays data in a manipulable table that enables operations like paging through, selecting, sorting, and editing of its items.

remarks.para: The Grid control is used to present data from a data source on a web page.

ComponentArt Grid provides the ability to define the behaviour of most operations via a single property: . This setting determines whether Grid operations such as paging, sorting and filtering are performed using postbacks or AJAX callbacks, or are done entirely on the client, with all the data pre-loaded.

General styling of the Grid's frame, header and footer areas is done via *CssClass properties on the Grid class itself. Styling of column headings and data cells is done on the class, which is used to control aspects of a table of data. This class also contains definitions for the columns to use from the data source. For this, the class is used. After data-binding, data is loaded from the data source into the collection, in the form of objects. Each GridItem corresponds to a row of data, and can be indexed by column name or index for accessing values in cells.

Besides CSS, Grid's presentation can be modified using templates. There are two kinds of templates which can be used: and . Client templates consist of markup and client-side binding expressions and are the suggested way of templating for situations where ASP.NET controls are not required.
For more information on templates in Web.UI, see Overview of Templates in Web.UI

member.name: T:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree
member.summary: 描述复合的树状的条件结构 与简单的一个表达式一样的结构对应 O 0 / \ / \ T I...(AND OR) T I (AND) / / \ T I I / \ I I I：表示简单结构的数据 T：表示复杂结构的数据，T没有具体的表达式，只记录一下关键的，就是多个下属的I或T之之间的关系（AND或OR） Test: a.id in (1,2,3) and a.name='adsfasdf''adfasdf''''adfasdf''' or a.type='aas' or a.test1 exists(select * from b where b.id in (1,2,3,4)) and 1=1 and (a.id = 1 or a.type=2) and (c.dfafd=adsfasf and c.daat='adfafda') and a.id between 10 and 20 分解后得到的对像应该是 tree ----- or -----and a.id in (1,2,3) a.name=''adsfasdf''adfasdf''''adfasdf''' -----and a.type='aas' -----and a.test1 exists(select * from b where b.id in (1,2,3)) 1=1 -------or a.id=1 a.type=2 --------and c.dfafd=adsfasf c.daat='adfafda' a.id between 10 and 20 结构为： OR |----------------------------------------|---------------------------------------| AND AND AND |------|---------| | |----------|------------------|--------------------------|----------------| a.id a.name a.type a.test1 1=1 OR AND a.id

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterParse.CanBindIntoItems(ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItem)
member.summary: 能否将一个对像直接加入到上一级的关联中 条件为： 1、上一级只有一种关联关系 2、上一级的关联关系与本条件相同 3、如果上一级为空，则默认可加

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterParse.CanBindIntoItems(ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItem,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree,System.Int32)
member.summary: 能否将一个对像直接加入到上一级的关联中 条件为：1、先检查单个条件是否能加，如果不能加，就直接返回。具体条件比较参见另一个方法。 2、如果此子树位于其父本的第一个位置，则可加； 3、如果子树 位于其父本的其它位置，需要比较关联关系是否一致，再确定能否加
member.param: 主树，需要将条件添加的树
上述单个条件所属的子树，可以为空
上述单个条件为主树的子树时，所处的位置，从0开始

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterParse.IsEqual(ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItem,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItem)
member.summary: 比较两个条件对像 严格对比所有属性，包括JoinType

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterParse.IsEqual(ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItem,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItem,System.Int32)
member.summary: 比较两个条件对像是否一样 根据条件来判断是否需要比较联接方法（And及OR）
member.param: 如果Pos大于0，则表明需要比较联接方式，如果Pos为0，则表示此对像位于条件的第一个，关联方式不作比较（因为其前一个比较对像不存在，没有意义）

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterParse.IsEqual(ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree)
member.summary: 比较条件树是否完全一样 比较树中所有条件，包括根一级树的关联方式（AND或OR）

member.name: M:ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterParse.IsEqual(ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree,ComponentArt.Web.UI.Search.FilterItemTree,System.Int32)
member.summary: 比较条件树是否完全一样 根据情况确定是否需要比较根一级树的关联方式。
member.param: 如果Pos大于0，表示需要比较根一级树的关联方式。如果Pos为0，表示不需要比较根一级树的关联方式（因为在它之前没有条件）
